DIV1.P: THE VILLAGE LAWYER: A FARCE, IN TWO ACTS, AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRES ROYAL IN LONDON AND DUBLIN, With universal Applause.
DUBLIN: PRINTED BY T. M'DONNEL, No. 50, ESSEX-STREET.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I.
DIV3.P: I Tell you it shall be—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Na! na! but my Dear, now!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: It does not signify talking—I must and will have it so.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: But think, my Dear, how ridiculous—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: I don't care—I'm resolv'd—I'll no longer be the laughing Stock of the whole Country; do you imagine I'll—
SP.STAGE: Enter Mr. Scout. Mrs. Scout following.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P:
Nay! but my dear sweet Love, that inde∣fatigable
Tongue of yours, would out-talk any Law∣yer in the Kingdom; I can talk sometimes pretty well myself, but I stand no chance with you—why, you would out-din the whole Bar itself, that tho' a Lawyer—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: A Lawyer! No one to see you in this Trim, would imagine you had ever carried a Cause in any Body's Suit but your own—had you a grain of Spirit left, you might—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Spirit! Nay, nay, Wife, don't complain of my want of Spirit; Was it not my Spirit that drove me from the Capital, and make me bury my Talents in Obscurity? Have not I attended all the Harangues of the Courts with only a little Whizzing on one side, and a Deafness on the other? And have not I con∣vinced you I had too much Spirit on a certain Oc∣casion?—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: Very fine indeed,—And so you make a Merit of your Blunders.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Blunders, indeed!—I think I made a Blun∣der in coming here—Not a single Job have I got since I have been down; not a broken Head, nor a Quarrel for one to get a Penny by—there has not been a Bastard born since we have been here! And, Damn me, if I don't think the very Cattle keep out of the Pound on purpose to spite me. Now, if one could put on the Appearance of Business, the Rea∣lity will follow of Course, and perhaps something may turn out.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: Yes, and in the mean Time, your poor Wife may starve, and your Daughter lose the Opportunity of settling herself handsomely with one of the young Men that pay their Addresses to her; which the Shabbiness of your Appearance has fright∣ened away.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Why, to be sure, I am Shabby enough of all Conscience, and cannot with any Propriety make my Appearance in Public.—Let me see—I have it—I'll go and purchase a Suit of Clothes directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: Purchase a Suit of Clothes without a Shilling in your Pocket?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: O, my Dear, that's nothing at all: most of the fashionable Suits in London are purchas∣ed that way. Let me see—what Colour shall I chuse? shall it be a Brown—a Grey—a Bat's-wing—or—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: Oh! never mind the Colour, so you can only find somebody Fool enough to let you have the Cloth.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: O, I'll warrant you. Let me see now—There's Neighbour Snarl now, that lives over the Way, he keeps a large Assortment of Colours, I'll hum him out of a Suit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: Mr. Snarl!—take care what you do there, Husband; his Son, Charles, is in Love with our Harriot, and would have married her before now, but for fear of his Father's Anger—I would not for the World disappoint the Girl's hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Well! well! step in and bring my Gown and Band—it will, at least, make me have a better Appearance, [Exit Mrs. Scout. by hiding these damned Rags of mine.—Come, Wife, make haste—take care you don't break the China Bason on the Window.—Come, what a long Time you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: Why, I brought it as soon as I could.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Come—help me on with it—take Care what you are about. See what a large Hole here is. You sit all Day with your Hands before you—and I think you might have mended it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: I'll mend it when you come back,

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: There—there—now I shall do very well! and let me tell you, Wife, I am not the only one that make use of a Gown to hide Things that are not fit to be seen.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Charles, have you been looking out for another Shepherd, as I told you?

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: No, Sir, I think you have got a very good one.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: No such Thing—I tell you that Sheep∣face is a Rogue—Here he has lived with me only a Fortnight, and there are missing Fourteen of my best Weathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Consider, Sir, what Havock such a Dis∣order makes in a little Time.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Yes, Yes,—I have considered—and I know pretty well by this Time. I have long suspected him—and last Night I caught him in the very Fact, killing one of my fattest Weathers; and am de∣termined to have him up before Justice Mittimus this Day—but reach me my Book, and let me look over the Account of my Flock, perhaps there may be more Missing.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: There it is, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: And if Neighbour Gripe call, tell him I want to talk with him about this Rascal, Sheepface.—Let me see—Twelve times Ten

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Sheepface—my Father has discovered all—do the best you can, beware saying too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Save you, good Master Snarl.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: What! you Rascal! are you here? how dare you appear before me after the Trick you play'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Only to tell you, I've been with Neigh∣bour Gripe, the Constable, who has been speaking to me about Sheep-stealing, Justice Mittimus, your Honour, and a power of Things—so I said to my∣self, as how I would not make it a Secret any longer with your good Workship.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Why! Fellow! this affected Simplicity won't serve your Purpose.—Did not I catch you last Night killing one of my fattest Weathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Only to keep it from Dying, by my Feckins.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: To keep it from Dying!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Of the Rot, an please your sweet Wor∣ship—it's a Way I learnt of our Doctor in the Parish, he cures most of his Patients the same Way.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: the Doctor, ha! the Doctors have a Li∣sence to kill from the College, but you have none, I believe. Why! there was not such a Breed in all the Kingdom for Spanish Wool!

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Please your Worship, satisfy yourself with the Blows you gave me, and make Matters up, if it be your Worship's good Will and Pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: But 'tis not my good Will and Pleasure—my good Will and Pleasure is to see you hanged, you Rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Oh! no; don't hang me!—consider that would be the Death of me! besides, your Worship, I was only married Yesterday—leave me alone for a Week or two, and who knows, but by that Time, I may save your Worship the Trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: No, no, the Gallows will be the best Way at first, and every bit as sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Heaven give you the Luck of it, good Master Snarl.—Since it must be so, I must go seek for a Lawyer, I find, or Might will prevail over Right.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Six times Twelve is Seventy-two—that is Right—then Nine times Seven is—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Egad! I have nick'd it nicely!—this was very lucky to catch him alone.—That seems to be a pretty piece of Cloth, and will just suit me. Good Morning to you, Mr. Snarl.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: O! what Neighbour Gripe! walk in.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: No, it's I, your Neighbour Scout.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I am my Neighbour Scout's most obedient—but I have no Business with him, at present, that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I'll make you tell a different Story presently, or I am much mistaken.—I call'd to settle a little Account.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I have no Account to settle with any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: There is a small Ballance of fifty Pounds—

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I know nothing at all about it; I don't owe any Man a Farthing in the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I wish I could say as much for myself, (aside.) Why, Sir, looking over my Father's Ac∣counts, I see he stands indebted to you fifty Pounds; and I, asan honest Man, am come to pay it.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.STAGE: (Turning round, rises, and shakes him by the Hand.)
SP.P: How do you do, Neighbour Scout? How do you do? I'm glad to see you!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Very well, I thank you, Sir. How do you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I think you live in our Village here.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, I do.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Pray be seated.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: By no Means, I fcar I disturb you?

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Oh! no, not at all, pray sit down—I in∣sist upon it.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Ah! Sir, if every body was of my Prin∣ciple, I should be a deal richer than I am; I cannot bear to be in any body's Debt.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Why? egad! the Generality of People bear it very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Very true, Sir, very true; when would you like to receive this Money? for I am impatient to pay every body.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Why, when you please.—No Time like the Time present.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Very true; I have it told out at home; but as I only hold my Father's Effects in Trust for my Daughter Harriot, for Form sake, you know it will be proper to have some of the other Guardians present at the Time of Payment.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Very true, it is so indeed!—Well, as soon as you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: What do you think of Three o'Clock this Afternoon?

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: A very good Time.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: And, egad! it happens very lucky—I have got a very fine Goose sent me by a Client from Norfolk, and you shall come and dine with me.—Are you fond of Goose?

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Very. It's my favourite Dish.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: That's very lucky. Don't forget to come. I think you do a deal of business here; more than all the Rest of the Trade around the Country.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Pretty well; I can't complain.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: And Mrs. Scout will dress the Goose by a valuable Receipt left her by her Great Uncle Al∣derman Dumpling.—Do you like it with Sage and Onion?

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Very much, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: You shall have it so. Why, you have such an engaging Way with you, that People take more Pleasure in paying you Money, than in re∣ceiving it from other People.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Ah, Sir, you slatter me!

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Not at all.—Egad! now I recollect—I promised Mr. Scout should have my Custom; and I don't care if I take a Coat to begin with.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, look over my Pattern's, here's a Variety of Colours.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: This seems to be a pretty Piece of Cloth.
SP.STAGE: (Feeling the Cloth that lies on the Counter.)

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Very fine, and good!—It's an Iron Grey.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Don't you remember our going to School together.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: What! along with old Iron Fist.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: The same. You was reckoned the prettist boy in the whole school.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Yes? my Mother said I always was a pretty boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: This Cloth seems very smooth and fine.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Right Spanish Wool I assure you!—Let, me send your Quantity to your House?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Stop! stop!—Pay as you go—pay as you go!—That is always my Maxim.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: And, egad, a very good Maxim 'tis!—I Wish all my Customers made Use of the same.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Don't you remember the tricks you used to play the Curate.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Yes, very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Ay, you was always full of mischsef—what is this Cloth a yard.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Why to any body else it should be Nine∣teen Shillings and Sixpence, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Now you are going to favour me.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: No, I am not; only as you are a particular friend, I won't charge you but Nineteen—And luckily here is just your quantity cut off.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: That's lucky, I'll take it home with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: By no means; my Boy—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Why would you take the poor Boy from his Work? I don't mind carrying it myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: But, let me measure it; perhaps there may be some Mistake?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: No mistake—dy'e think I doubt your word,

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: But the price!—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Never mind that, I leave it entirely to you.—Well, good Morning—Don't forget the Goose:—You'll be sure to be there Time enough to dine, before you receive your Money. Good Morn∣ing—Don't forget.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P:
Demme but he's carried off my cloth.—But he'll pay: O yes, he'll pay; for he must be a very honest Man, or he never would have told me of the fifty Pounds, and invite me to dine off the Goose into the Bargain. I am sorry I cheated him in the
Cloth—but no Matter; it is the Way I got all my Money.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: If you wants a Lawyer to get you fairly out of a Scrape, my Master's the Man for your Money, Sheepface.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: I remember he stood my Friend before, from being hanged at York!—and, would you be∣lieve it, only for mending the Complexion of a bald faced Horse; and I don't know how it was, I have such a treacherous Memory: but some how or other—I forgot to pay him.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: O never mind—he won't remember that; but be very careful not to tell him your Master's Name.—I know he would not be concerned against Mr. Snarl, for the World!

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: No, no—I'll only tell him 'tis my Master, and he'll think I mean the rich Farmer I lived with formerly.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Well, well—that will do—but here he comes, I'll go in.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Egad I think I have made a good Morn∣ing's Work!—This cloth will enable me to make a genteel Appearance.—But who have we here? sure I should know that Face.—Hark ye, Sir!—Didn't I save you and your Brother from being hanged some Time ago, at York?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: And by the same Rule, I think one of you forgot to pay me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: That was Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: One of you got off clear, and the other died soon after in Prison?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: That was not I!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: No, no—I see it was not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: For all that I was sicker than my Brother;—but I am come to ask your Worship to stand my Friend against a—his Worship, my Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: What! the rich Farmer here, that lives in the Neighbourhood?

SP.SPEAKER: Shep.
SP.P: Yes, yes—he lives in the Neighbourhood sure enough;—and if you will stand my Friend, you shall be paid to your Heart's Content.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Aye! Now you speak to the Purpose:—Come, you must tell me how it was.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P:
Why you must know my Master gives me
but small Wages—very small Wages indeed!—So I thought I might as well do a little Business on my own Account, and so make myself Amends without any Damage to him, with an honest Neighbour of mine—a little Bit of a Butcher by Trade.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Well! But what Business can you have to do with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Why, saving your Worship's Presence—I hinders the Sheep from dying of the Rot.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Ah!—How do you contrive that?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: I cuts their Throats before it comes to them.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: What!—I suppose then your Master thinks that you kill his Sheep for the sake of selling their Carcasses?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Yes, and I cannot beat it out of his Head for the Soul of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Well; then you must tell me all the parti∣culars about it.—Relate every Circumstance, and don't hide a single Item.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Why, then Sir, you must know—that last Night, as I was going down,—(Must I tell the Truth?)—

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Yes, yes—You must tell the Truth here, or we shall never be able to lie to the Purpose any where else.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P:
Well then—Last Night after I was mar∣ried, having a little leisure Time upon my Hands, I goes down to our Penn, and as I was musing on I
don't know what, out I takes my Knife, and hap∣pening by mere accident, saving your Worship's presence, to put it under the throat of one of the fattest Wethers; I don't know how it came about, but I had not been long there, before the Wether died, and all of a sudden, as a Body may say.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: What! and somebody was looking on all the while?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Yes, Master from behind the Hedge, and would have it, it died all along with me.—And so as you see—he laid such a Shower of Blows on me, that it kept the Bride out of Temper all Night—But I hope your Worship will stand my Friend, and not let me lose the Fruits of my honest Labour—all at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Why, there are two Ways of settling this Business—and one is, I think, to be done without putting you to any Expence.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Let's try that first by all Means.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: You have scraped up something in your Master's Service?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: I have been up late and early for it, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I suppose you have taken Care to have your Savings all in hard Cash?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Well, then, when you go Home, take it and hide it in the safest Place you can find.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, that I'll do.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I'll take Care your Master shall pay all Costs d Charges.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Aye, so he ought—he can afford it.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: It shall be nothing out of your Pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: That's just as I would have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: He'll have all the Trouble and the Expence of bringing you to Trial, and after that have the Pleasure of seeing you hanged.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Let's take the other Way.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Well!—let me see—I suppose he'll take out a Warant against you, and have you taken before Justice Mittimus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: So I understand.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I think the Justice's Credulity is easily im∣posed on:—so when you are ordered before him, I'll attend, and to all the Questions that you are asked, answer nothing, but imitate the Voice of the Lambs, when they bleat afte the Ewes—You can speak that Dialect.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: It's my Mother Tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: But if I bring you off clear, I expect to be very well paid for this.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: So you shall—I'll pay you to your Heart's Content.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Be sure you answer nothing but Baa!

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Baa!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Aye! that will do very well—Be sure stick to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheep.
SP.P: Yes, your Worship—Never fear I—What Trouble a Body has to keep one's own in this World.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE IV.
DIV3.P: Aye, aye—that's my Neighbour Scout's House—he is just come Home to give orders about the Din∣ner, I warrant—Egad, I think I shall make a good Day's Work—What with the Fifty Pounds his Fa∣ther owed mine—which, by the bye, I know no∣thing at all about—and the money for the Cloth—and the Goose that is to be dress'd by a famous Re∣ceipt from Alderman Dumpling's.—Egad, I be∣lieve they are dressing it now—I'll in, and see what is going forward.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Wife, wife—come along—I think I hear Snarl at the Door: come to your Place, and mind your Cue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: Never fear me—I warrant I shall make an excellent Nurse.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Where is my Friend Mr. Scout?—Is the Goose a Dressing?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Wife, Wife—Here comes the Doctor—he brings me the cooling Mixture—the cooling Mix∣ture!

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: The cooling Mixture!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: Oh, Sir! I hope you have brought something for my poor Husband; he has been con∣fined to his Room, and has not been out this Fort∣night.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Not out of his Room this Fortnight!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: No, Sir, This Day Fortnight, of all the good Days in the Year, he was seized with a Lunacy Fit, and has not been out of Doors, since.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Snarl.
SP.P: Why, Woman! What are you talk∣ing about?—Why he came to my Shop this Morn∣ing, and by the same Token, bought four Yards of Iron Grey Cloth, and I am come for my Money.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: This Morning!

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: This Morning! and invited me to dine with him To-day off a Goose, and to receive fifty Pounds which his Father owed mine.—I'll speak to him—How d'ye do, good Mr. Scout?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Oh! how d'ye do good Mr. Drench?

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Good Mr. Drench!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: He takes you for the Doctor, Mr. Drench.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Wife, Wife—keep the Doctor frome me, and a Fig for the Disease.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: For Heaven's Sake, Sir, if you can't relieve him, don't torment him.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Hold your Tongue Woman. I want my Cloth or my Money. Mr. Scout!—Mr. Scout!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: See! see! see!—there is three nice Butter∣slies, there they fly! there they fly! (Jumps after them) with bt wings.—I've batch'd them—I have them—I have them—Tally-ho, Tally-ho!—Oh! oh! oh!

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Butterflies!—Damme if I can see any.—I wish to see my Cloth.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: My Lord, and Gen∣tlemen of the Jury—My Client Sir Hugh Wither∣ington, charges the Defendant Mr. Mungummery,—that is moreover, nevertheless, as shall appear as—(spits at him)—(Jumps down and dances)—Dol! de rol de lol! Oh! oh! oh!—(Jumps cross-legg'd o the ).

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: There now, he's fancying himself a Tay∣l, and at Work upon my Cloth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Scout.
SP.P: Do, pray Sir, leave him, and don't torment him.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I won't leave him without my Money—See he is getting better.—I'll speak to him again.—How d'ye do neighbour Scout?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: How d'ye do Mr. Snarl?—I am glad to see you,—I hope you are very well? My dear here is Mr. Snarl come to see us!

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: There! there! there! he knows me—he knows me.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Oh Mr. Snarl, I beg a thousand pardons; I confess I have been very unkind; but I hope you'l excuse me for not coming to see you. I have never called on you since I come to live in this Part of the Country.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P:
Never called on me! Oh, the Devil! I shall never get my Cloth again.—Why Man you called on me this Morning, and bought four Yards
of Iron Grey Cloth, and I am come for my Money. Besides fifty Pounds your Father owed mine—Aye▪ you may shake your head; but dam'me If I go out of the House without it.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Say you so? then I'll try some thing else. (Aside.) Wife! Wife! Wife! get up—softly! softly! get up!—don't lie snoring there—there's Thieves in the House. No, no.—Second Thoughts, be still, while I fetch my Gun and shoot them. Cover yourself up close; I'll shoot them! shoot them! shoot them!

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Thieves in the House did he say? Egad▪ who knows but in his mad Tricks, he may shoot me for a Thief? I'll get out of his Way, and not stay with a Madman.
SP.STAGE: Enter Scout with a Birch Broom, and presents it at him. Boh!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Victoria! Victoria!—Huzza.

SP.SPEAKER: Justice.
SP.P: So the Court being assembled the Par∣ties may appear.
Where's your Lawyer, neighbour Snarl?

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: I am my own Lawyer, I shall employ no∣body, that would cost more Money.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Why, how now you Rascal, have you im∣posed upon me? What's the meaning of all this? is that the Plaintiff?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Yes, that's his Honour, my good Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: O! the Devil! What shall I do? I must stay and brazen it out! If I sneak out of Court it will cause suspicion.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Come, neighbour Snarl, begin.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Well then, that Thief, there—

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: No abuse! no abuse!

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P:
Well then, I say that Rascal my Shepherd—
No—do my eyes deceive me, sure that is—yes—it must be he—if I had not left him very bad I could have sworn—yes, yes, 'tis him, and that other Ras∣cal came to my Shop and bought—No, No,—I don't mean so—that Rascal there has killed fourteen of my fattest Weathers. What answer do you make to that?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: I deny the fact.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: What is become of them then.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: They did die of the rot.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: 'Tis him—his Voice too—

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: What proof have you got.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Why this Morning he came to my house—No, No, I mean I went down last night to the pens, having long suspected him—'tis he! 'tis he and he began a long Story about Fifty Pounds, No, No, I don't mean that, and there I caught him in the very fact.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: That remains to be proved.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Yes, I'll swear 'tis the very man.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Why this is the very man, but is it certain that your weathers died of the rot, what answer do you make to that?

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Why, I tell you, he came this very morning, and after talking some time, makes no more to do thancarries off four yards of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Four yards of your weathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: No, no, four yards of my Cloth, I mean that other Thief, that other there.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: What other! What other, neighbour Snarl?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Why he's mad, an please your Worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Truly I think so too, hark'ye neighbour Snarl, not all the Justices in the Country, no nor their Clerks neither, can make any thing of your evidence. Stick to your Weathers! stick to your Weathers! or I must release the prisoner; but howe∣ver I believe it will be the shortest way to examine him myself, come here my good fellow, hold up your head, don't be frightened, tell me your name.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Baa—

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: It's a lie! it's a lie! His name is Sheepface.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Well, well, Sheepface or Baa, no matter for the name, did Mr. Snarl give you in charge four score Sheep, Sheepface?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Baa!

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: I say did Mr. Snarl catch you in the night killing one of his fattest Weathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Baa.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: What does he mean by Baa?

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Please your Worship, the blows he gave this poor fellow on the head has so affected his senses, he can say nothing else; he is to be trepann'd as soon as the Court breaks up, and the Doctors say it is the whole Materia Medica, against a dose of Jalup, he never recovers.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: But the Act, and in that case provided, for∣bids all blows, particularly on the head.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: It was dark, and when I strike, I never mind where the blows fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: A voluntary confession, a voluntary con∣fession!

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: A voluntary confession indeed, release the prisoner, I find no cause of complaint against him.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: No cause of complaint against him! you are a pretty Justice indeed, one kills my Sheep, and the other pays me with Sir Hugh Witherington, and then you can see no cause of complaint against him.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Not I truly.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: A pretty day's work I have made indeed, a Suit of Law, and a Suit of Iron-grey Cloth both carried against me; but as for you Mr. Lawyer, we shall meet again.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: O fie, neighbour Snarl, you're to blame; very much to blame indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Come, now it's all over, go and thank his Worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Baa, Baa, Baa!

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Enough, enough, my good fellow, take care you don't catch cold in your Head, go and get trepann'd, and take care of yourself, Sheepface.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Baa!

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Poor fellow! poor fellow!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P:
Bravo my Boy! you have acted your part admirably, and I think I did very well to bring you off so cleverly; and now I make no doubt but as
you are a very honest Fellow, you'll pay me as gene∣rous as you promis'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Baa!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Aye! very well, very well indeed—you did that very well just now, but there's no occasion to have it over any more—I'm talking about my fee you know Sheepface!—Yes, yes, I tell you it was very well done, but at this time you know my fee is the question.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Baa, Baa!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: How's this, am I laughed at, pay me di∣rectly you Rascal or I'll play the Devil with you! I'll teach you try to cheat a Lawyer that lives by cheat∣ing others, I'll—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Baa!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: What again! braved by a Mongril Cur, a bleating Bellweather! a—

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Baa!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Out of my sight, or Ill break every bone in your Dog's skin, you Sheep-slealing Scoundrel, would you cheat one that has cheated hundreds? get home to your hiding place.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Baa!

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Away, and mind how you and your wife play the rest of your parts, and perhaps I may for∣give you if we succeed; if not I will make an exam∣ple of you, you Rascal!

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Baa, Baa!

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Poor fellow! Like to die you say,

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: Yes your Worship—Oh dear!

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Well, well, comfort yourself, remember you was only married Yesterday.

SP.SPEAKER: Kate.
SP.P: That's the very thing, Sir, if he had but lived a little longer I should not have cared so much about it, but to be cut off just in the Honey Moon is very hard, Oh! Oh! Oh! But I am not re∣vengeful, and your Worship knows how much I love my Master's Daughter Harriet; and Charles, Mr. Snarl's Son is in love with her, but his Father won't agree to the Match.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: O, I understand you, so you'll hush up matters, provided he'll agree to the Marriage; well, what say you neighbour Scout.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Why! why, I don't know what to say to it, as you all seem willing to settle the Business, I don't like to stand out, and so I agree to it. But I think your Worship, I had better go in and fill up the blanks of a Bond and make him sign it, or when all is over he'll retract from his word.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Well do so! Here he comes, go! go!
So neighbour Snarl, I find that the blows that you gave the poor Fellow on the Head, has occasioned his Death.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Oh, the Devil!

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: But hark'ye neighbour, I've got a proposal to make, which perhaps may not be disagreeable to you; your Son Charles it seems is in love with Har∣riet, Lawyer Scout's Daughter—Now, I believe' Sheepface's wife would hush up matters, provided you'll consent to the match.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Consent! why I suppose I must, in order to save myself from further expence, a very pretty day's work I have made on't truly.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Here your Worship, I have filled up a Bond, in order that he may sign whatever is agreed to, how d'ye do neighbour Snarl—I always cut my Coat—

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: According to my Cloth.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Come, come! sign, sign!
Bring him along neighbour Hobnail.

SP.SPEAKER: Just.
SP.P: Hey dey! where did this fellow come from?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: I come from necessity your Worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Snarl.
SP.P: Hey dey! What the plague are you not dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: No, your Worship could never beat such a thing into my Head.

SP.SPEAKER: Charles.
SP.P: Dear Sir, don't be angry, Sheepface has done nothing but by my directions, and I hope you'll not only forgive him, but enable me by your future Generosity to provide for ourselves hencefor∣ward.

SP.SPEAKER: Sheepface.
SP.P: Do take back one of your best Sheep.

SP.SPEAKER: Scout.
SP.P: Well, as we have settled our own affairs thus far, we must now appeal to the Tribunal, and humbly ask their permission for the Village Lawyer, to continue in Practice.
